Black hole genealogy: A new way to discover 'ancestors' of cosmic phenomena - Phys.org
SpaceX’s 31st Dragon cargo capsule returns to Earth with splashdown off Florida coast - Space.com
summary:
SpaceX’s 31st Dragon cargo capsule returns to Earth with splashdown off Florida coast

Date: December 17, 2023
Source: Space.com

SpaceX's 31st robotic cargo mission has successfully returned to Earth.

The Dragon cargo capsule splashed down off the Florida coast at 1:39 p.m. EDT, bringing back thousands of pounds of equipment and experiment specimens from the International Space Station (ISS).

  • The capsule is the only ISS cargo spacecraft capable of returning equipment and experiments safely to Earth.
  • It launched from NASA's Kennedy Space Center on Nov. 4, delivering about 6,000 pounds of supplies for astronauts aboard the ISS.
  • The astronauts onboard include NASA’s Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, who had extended stays due to complications with the Boeing Starliner mission.
  • The delivered cargo included fresh food, research equipment, and personal items for the astronauts.
NASA will retrieve the CRS-31 Dragon spacecraft relatively quickly to continue research in the post-microgravity environment.

This successful splashdown reaffirms the reliability of SpaceX's cargo missions and their importance in supporting ISS operations.
newTitle: SpaceX’s 31st Dragon Cargo Capsule Returns to Earth with Splashdown Off Florida Coast

title: Scientists warn of ‘unprecedented’ risks of research into mirror life - CNN
Straight From a Sci-Fi Movie: Scientists Capture First-Ever Close-Up Image of a Dying Star From Another Galaxy! - Indian Defence Review
summary:
Scientists Capture First-Ever Close-Up Image of a Dying Star From Another Galaxy

Published on: December 17, 2024 | Source: Indian Defence Review

Astronomers have achieved a groundbreaking milestone by capturing the first-ever close-up image of a star outside of our Milky Way galaxy, WOH G64. Located approximately 160,000 light-years away in the Large Magellanic Cloud, this new image reveals details about a star that could be on the verge of a supernova explosion.

  • WOH G64 is a supergiant star, around 1,500 times the size of the Sun.
  • Astronomers suggest it may explode in 10,000 to 100,000 years.
  • Keiichi Ohnaka commented on the slow pace of stellar evolution, noting the star's significant dimming.
  • The image was taken using the European Southern Observatory’s Very Large Telescope Interferometer.
  • This discovery enhances understanding of the lifecycle of stars and the processes leading to supernovae.
“Just before, in an astronomical sense. Not today or next week or next year.” - Keiichi Ohnaka

This extraordinary breakthrough allows for observations of supernova processes, providing vital clues that may enrich our understanding of stellar deaths and the cosmic elements they create.
newTitle: Scientists Capture First-Ever Close-Up Image of a Dying Star From Another Galaxy

title: 8 Stunning Space Images Released by NASA in 2024 - WION
summary:
8 Stunning Space Images Released by NASA in 2024

Date: Dec 17, 2024

Source: WION

This article presents a selection of breathtaking space images taken by NASA's James Webb Space Telescope, showcasing various astronomical wonders.

  • NGC 628: A spiral galaxy located 32 million light-years away, featuring a densely populated star region amidst bright orange gas.
  • Duo of Starbursts in I Zwicky 18: An irregular dwarf galaxy that highlights two star formation regions surrounded by hot gas bubbles.
  • Horsehead Nebula: A stunning cloud of dust and gas, ideal for studying star interactions.
  • The Crab Nebula: A remnant of a supernova explosion, home to a neutron star radiating energy.
  • Orion Nebula: Captured using both Chandra and Webb telescopes, showcasing a prominent star formation region.
  • Rho Ophiuchi: A composite image illustrating a complex gas and star region located approximately 390 light-years away.
  • Pillars of Creation: A star-forming region with vibrant young stars among pillars of dust and gas.
  • Perseus (NGC 1333): Showcases a nearby star-forming region with large, bright stars surrounded by glowing gas.
newTitle: 8 Stunning Space Images Released by NASA in 2024

title: 7 amazing photos of celestial bodies shared by NASA Hubble Space Telescope - See now - India.com
summary:
7 Amazing Photos of Celestial Bodies Shared by NASA Hubble Space Telescope

Published on: December 2024 by India.com

This article showcases stunning images captured by NASA's Hubble Space Telescope, highlighting various celestial bodies within and outside our solar system.

  • Large Magellanic Cloud, a dwarf galaxy orbiting the Milky Way.
  • PIA24380, a swiftly rotating brown dwarf.
  • Galaxy Arp 148, taken by NASA's Spitzer and Hubble telescopes.
  • LDN 1551, featuring the star system XZ Tauri.
  • Overview of our solar system.
"Our solar system consists of the Sun and celestial bodies bound to it by gravity, including planets, moons, asteroids, and comets."

This collection of images not only provides awe-inspiring visuals but also deepens our understanding of the universe and its mysteries.

title: 'Dark comets': Nasa studies mysterious new kids in our solar system - India Today
summary:
NASA Studies Mysterious 'Dark Comets' in Our Solar System

Published On: December 17, 2024 Source: indiatodayglobal

NASA is investigating a new class of celestial bodies known as “dark comets,” which lack the bright tails typical of comets and resemble asteroids more closely.

  • Dark comets were first suggested by the unusual orbital deviations of asteroid 2003 RM in 2016.
  • NASA has confirmed 14 dark comets, categorized into “outer dark comets” and “inner dark comets.”
  • These celestial objects may hold crucial information about the origins of life on Earth.
  • Dark comets present challenges for planetary defense due to their unpredictable orbits.
  • NASA's advanced instruments, including DECam, are being used to identify these elusive targets.
“Dark comets are a new potential source for having delivered the materials to Earth that were necessary for the development of life,” says Darryl Seligman.

As NASA continues its research, dark comets could reveal important insights into the early Solar System and the origins of life on Earth.
newTitle: NASA Studies Mysterious 'Dark Comets' in Our Solar System

title: Ursid meteor shower 2024: The final meteor shower of the year - India Today
summary:
Ursid meteor shower 2024: The final meteor shower of the year

Published On: Dec 17, 2024

Source: indiatodayglobal

The Ursid meteor shower, peaking December 21-22, marks the year's final celestial display, originating from Comet 8P/Tuttle's debris. It radiates from Ursa Minor, offering 5-10 meteors per hour under ideal conditions.

  • The Ursid meteor shower peaks on December 21-22.
  • Offers 5-10 meteors per hour under ideal viewing conditions.
  • Observed for just over a century, with bursts occasionally observed.
  • Historical bursts of up to 100 meteors per hour occurred in 1945 and 1986.
  • The next meteor shower, the Quadrantids, peaks on January 2-3, 2025.
According to EarthSky.org, in rare instances, 100 or more meteors per hour bursts have been observed.

The Ursids hold special significance as the final meteor shower of the year, offering a captivating experience for astronomy enthusiasts and the public.
newTitle: Ursid Meteor Shower 2024: The Final Celestial Show of the Year

title: Webb Telescope Confirms Planet-Forming Disks Last Longer in Early Universe - Gadgets 360
summary:
Webb Telescope Confirms Planet-Forming Disks Last Longer in Early Universe

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Gadgets360

The NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope has resolved the mystery of planet formation in the early universe, revealing that planet-forming disks around stars lasted much longer than previously thought.

  • Planet-forming disks were found around stars in the Small Magellanic Cloud, defying earlier theories.
  • Planets could form despite the absence of heavier elements like carbon and iron.
  • The research suggests that these disks can last up to 30 million years, challenging existing models predicting shorter lifespans.
“Disks indeed surround these stars and are still in the process of gobbling material.” - Guido De Marchi, study lead

This groundbreaking discovery will reshape our understanding of planetary evolution in the universe.
newTitle: Webb Telescope Confirms Longer Lifespans of Planet-Forming Disks in Early Universe

NASA Alerts: 84-Foot Asteroid to Make Close Approach to Earth Tomorrow - The Hans India
Is the planet Earth in danger? What was found in the asteroid belt between Jupiter and Mars by the James W - The Economic Times
summary:
Asteroids Found in the Belt Between Jupiter and Mars Pose Potential Threat to Earth

Publication Date: October 2023, Source: Economic Times

Recent discoveries made by the James Webb Space Telescope have identified numerous small asteroids in the asteroid belt between Jupiter and Mars, highlighting potential threats to Earth due to their frequency of impact.

  • A large number of small asteroids are present in the asteroid belt.
  • Smaller asteroids pose a greater threat due to their frequency of impact.
  • New computational methods using GPUs have been developed for better detection of these asteroids.
  • The JWST has identified 138 new decameter-sized asteroids, with six being of particular concern for Earth's orbit.
  • Future advances in asteroid detection may help monitor these threatening objects more effectively.
“Thirty times as much energy was released when a relatively small asteroid exploded over Chelyabinsk, Russia, ten years ago.”

This discovery emphasizes the importance of monitoring smaller asteroids, which could potentially cause significant damage due to their frequency and the inability to detect them easily.
newTitle: Asteroids Found in the Belt Between Jupiter and Mars Pose Potential Threat to Earth

title: Perseverance Mars Rover Is Finally Out of the Jezero Crater, Whole New Alien World Ahead - autoevolution
The stars are waiting: Researchers determine frozen sperm can remain viable in space for 200 years - The Jerusalem Post
summary:
The stars are waiting: Researchers determine frozen sperm can remain viable in space for 200 years

Date: DECEMBER 17, 2024 | Source: The Jerusalem Post

Scientists have successfully produced healthy baby mice from freeze-dried sperm stored in space, showing that such sperm can remain viable for up to 200 years.

  • The study was led by Professor Teruhiko Wakayama of the University of Yamanashi.
  • Sperm was stored in a freezer aboard the International Space Station for up to six years.
  • This research is crucial for future human colonization of other planets, focusing on preserving genetic resources for potential catastrophic events on Earth.
  • Challenges of reproduction in space include radiation damage to DNA and the effects of microgravity on embryonic development.
  • Research aims to safeguard Earth's genetic diversity as humanity looks to live on the Moon and Mars.
“If we can confirm this, it will reassure us. And if it doesn’t succeed, we need to understand how to address this challenge.” - Professor Teruhiko Wakayama

The findings are significant as they may influence future space missions and our understanding of reproduction beyond Earth.
newTitle: Research Shows Frozen Sperm Can Last 200 Years in Space

title: NASA’s Juno Mission Provides Groundbreaking Insights Into Volcanic Heat Of Io, Jupiter’s Largest Moon - News18
summary:
NASA’s Juno Mission Provides Groundbreaking Insights Into Volcanic Heat Of Io, Jupiter’s Largest Moon

Date: December 17, 2024

Source: News18

The Juno mission has shed light on the volcanic activity of Io, revealing that its volcanoes are powered by localized magma chambers rather than a global magma ocean, changing our understanding of its geology.

  • Io is the most volcanically active body in the solar system with over 400 active volcanoes.
  • The volcanic eruptions are powered by tidal flexing from Jupiter's gravitational influence.
  • Data collected by Juno indicates localized magma chambers provide energy for the eruptions.
  • These findings could influence the study of other potentially habitable moons like Europa and Enceladus.
“The squeezing generates heat to the extent that Io’s insides are melting and erupting,” - Scott Bolton, Juno’s principal investigator.

The Juno mission’s discoveries not only clarify the nature of volcanic activity on Io but also invite a reevaluation of how tidal forces impact other celestial bodies.
newTitle: NASA’s Juno Mission Reveals Volcanic Secrets of Io, Jupiter’s Largest Moon

title: Boltz-1: A model to predict biomolecular structures - Tech Explorist
summary:
Boltz-1: A Model to Predict Biomolecular Structures

Publication Date: December 17, 2024
Source: MIT News

MIT scientists have introduced Boltz-1, an innovative open-source AI model aimed at predicting biomolecular structures with high accuracy, similar to existing models while encouraging community collaboration.

Key Points:

  • Boltz-1 is the first fully open-source model achieving performance on par with AlphaFold3.
  • The model was developed by the MIT Jameel Clinic for Machine Learning in Health.
  • Researchers focused on improving prediction efficiency and accuracy through new algorithms.
  • Boltz-1's entire development pipeline is open-sourced for further scientific collaboration.
  • MIT researchers call for community contributions to enhance Boltz-1 continuously.
“We hope for this to be a starting point for the community...This is not the end of the line. We want as much contribution from the community as we can get.” - Gabriele Corso

Conclusion: Boltz-1 represents a significant leap in the field of biomolecular prediction, fostering open collaboration among researchers for future advancements.
newTitle: Boltz-1: A Model to Predict Biomolecular Structures

title: NASA’s DaVinci to probe ancient terrain, lower atmosphere of Venus - News9 LIVE
summary:
NASA is dispatching the DaVinci probe to Venus in the early 2030s. The spacecraft will be the first to image the surface in 40 years.

Publication Date: New Delhi
Source: News9 Live

NASA is developing its Deep Atmosphere Venus Investigation of Noble gases, Chemistry, and Imaging (DaVinci) mission to Venus that consists of two elements, a spacecraft to conduct flybys and a probe that will descend into the atmosphere of the Earth. The mission is slotted for launch in the early 2030s. The probe will be the first to investigate the ancient portions of the Venusian terrain, known as tessera, with a particular focus on alpha Region.

  • The DaVinci probe will examine chemical composition in the lower regions of Venus's atmosphere.
  • Measurements will be conducted from an altitude of 27 kilometers to the surface.
  • The mission aims to illuminate the history of water on Venus and understand its greenhouse gas effect.
  • Multiple missions, including VERITAS and ESA's Envision, will probe Venus alongside DaVinci.
“Understanding more about Venus can help scientists better understand the dynamics of our own atmosphere, as well as the atmospheres of distant exoplanets.”

DaVinci will utilize a parachute to slow its descent, allowing its instruments to gather data effectively as it explores Venus in unprecedented detail.
newTitle: NASA’s DaVinci Probe Set to Explore Venus in the 2030s

title: Astronomers capture intense gamma-ray burst from supermassive monster black hole - Moneycontrol
NASA's James Webb Telescope spots 138 new asteroids, including Earth-threatening ones - India TV News
summary:
NASA's James Webb Telescope Discovers 138 New Asteroids, Including Potentially Hazardous Ones

Publication Date: December 9, 2024 | Source: Nature

Astronomers using data from the James Webb Space Telescope have uncovered a significant number of new asteroids located in the main belt between Mars and Jupiter, with some on orbits that could bring them close to Earth.

  • A total of 138 new asteroids were identified.
  • Some of these asteroids could pose a threat to Earth.
  • Discovery made possible by revisiting old JWST data initially aimed at the TRAPPIST-1 star system.
  • Largest asteroids are compared in size to several stadiums.
  • The findings may lead to increased understanding and observation of smaller asteroids.
“This is a sign of a new population regime of asteroids,” said Julien de Wit, an Associate Professor of Planetary Science at MIT.

Looking forward, continued observations may reveal thousands more asteroids, enhancing monitoring for potential threats to Earth.
newTitle: NASA's James Webb Telescope Discovers 138 New Asteroids, Including Potentially Hazardous Ones

title: NASA reports on Ingenuity Mars helicopter accident - EarthSky
summary:
NASA Reports on Ingenuity Mars Helicopter Accident

Publication Date: December 11, 2024

Source: NASA

The Ingenuity Mars helicopter, which made history by achieving powered flight on Mars, was permanently grounded after sustaining damage during its 72nd flight on January 18, 2024. The accident was attributed to navigation system issues amidst featureless terrain.

  • The helicopter's rotor blades were damaged during its final flight, leading to its grounding.
  • Navigation system failures are believed to have caused the accident, stemming from the terrain it flew over.
  • Ingenuity originally aimed for five flights but achieved 72, significantly surpassing expectations.
“When running an accident investigation from 100 million miles away, you don’t have any black boxes or eyewitnesses.” - Håvard Grip, JPL

This incident marks a significant chapter in the Ingenuity mission, which provided valuable aerial scouting for the Perseverance rover.
newTitle: NASA Reports on Ingenuity Mars Helicopter Accident

title: Ursid Meteor Shower 2024: Dates, Viewing Tips, and Best Times - Gadgets 360
summary:
Ursid Meteor Shower 2024: Dates, Viewing Tips, and Best Times

Publication Date: 2024-12-21 Source: Gadgets 360

The Ursids meteor shower will peak on the night of December 21 to 22, 2024, coinciding with the winter solstice in the Northern Hemisphere, with an expected display of around 10 meteors per hour.

  • The Ursids will be active from December 17 to 26.
  • Best viewing is expected before dawn on December 22.
  • The meteors originate from Comet 8P/Tuttle.
  • Holding a location away from artificial lights can enhance viewing experiences.
  • Observers should allow their eyes to adjust to the dark.
"Meteor showers like the Ursids are best observed with the unaided eye."

In conclusion, despite the competition from the Geminids earlier in the month, the Ursids offer a captivating skywatching opportunity for fans of astronomy.
newTitle: Ursid Meteor Shower 2024: Dates, Viewing Tips, and Best Times

title: Dead on Mars: InSight lander reveals how dust devil moves on Red Planet - MSN
Scientists Warn: Mirror Bacteria Could Become Humanity’s Unseen Threat - The Daily Galaxy --Great Discoveries Channel
summary:
Scientists Warn: Mirror Bacteria Could Become Humanity’s Unseen Threat

Publication Date: October 2023, Source: Science

A group of 38 top scientists warns that the development of "mirror bacteria"—organisms with reversed molecular structures—could lead to catastrophic consequences, possibly introducing pathogens resistant to current biological defenses.

The Concept of Mirror Bacteria

Chirality, or molecular handedness, is crucial for life. Unlike natural bacteria, mirror bacteria would have reversed molecular structures, posing significant risks.

Key Differences Between Natural Bacteria and Mirror Bacteria

Risks of Mirror Bacteria

  • Immune system failures: Leading to lethal infections.
  • Ecosystem disruption: Harm to plants, wildlife, and agriculture.
  • Resistance to control: Antibiotics and natural predators may be ineffective.

“It’s a genie you don’t want to let out of the bottle. The risk of something bad happening is low, but the consequences of something bad happening are really awful.” - Jonathan Jones

Call for Caution

Scientists urge a halt in mirror bacteria research until safety can be ensured, reflecting on the ethical implications and potential hazards associated with pursuing such knowledge.
newTitle: Scientists Warn: Mirror Bacteria Could Become Humanity’s Unseen Threat

title: NASA's helicopter wreck on Mars could have a new purpose for the next two decades - UNILAD
summary:
NASA's Ingenuity Helicopter Wreck on Mars: A New Purpose Unveiled

Date: February 18, 2024 | Source: UNILAD

The Ingenuity helicopter, which made history by achieving powered flight on Mars, has a new role despite its recent crash after three years of operations.

  • The helicopter successfully traveled 293 million miles to Mars, landing on February 18, 2021.
  • Ingenuity’s mission ended with a crash on January 18, 2024, during its 72nd flight.
  • Following the crash, NASA confirmed that Ingenuity’s systems remain functional.
  • The helicopter is now being used as a weather station, relaying data weekly to NASA's Perseverance rover.
  • Ingenuity’s avionics data is aiding future aerospace designs for Mars missions.
Teddy Tzanetos, Ingenuity’s project manager, stated, "We’re now approaching four years of continuous operations, suggesting that not everything needs to be bigger, heavier, and radiation-hardened to work in the harsh Martian environment."

Despite its damage, Ingenuity continues to contribute valuable data that will benefit upcoming explorations of Mars.
newTitle: NASA's Ingenuity Helicopter Wreck on Mars: A New Purpose Unveiled

title: Scientists call for efforts to create an AI-based virtual human cell - INDIAai
summary:
Scientists Call for Global Efforts to Create an AI-Based Virtual Human Cell

Publication Date: N/A Source: N/A

An initiative led by researchers from Stanford and the Chan-Zuckerberg Initiative aims to leverage AI to simulate human cells, potentially revolutionizing biology.

  • Researchers believe we have an unprecedented opportunity to model human biology using AI.
  • The goal is to create a virtual human cell that accurately simulates cellular functions and dynamics.
  • This could lead to faster drug development and personalized medicine through in silico experiments.
  • Success would depend on universal representations across species and the ability to test hypotheses without physical experiments.
  • A global collaboration is essential, reminiscent of the Human Genome Project.
“This is a mammoth project... the time is ripe for science to unite and begin the work of revolutionizing the way we understand and model biology.” - Emma Lundberg

In conclusion, a successful AI virtual cell could transform our understanding of biology and medical science, making it crucial for global collaboration in the effort.
newTitle: Scientists Call for Global Efforts to Create an AI-Based Virtual Human Cell

title: Trappist-1 b may host an atmosphere after all - News9 LIVE
summary:
Trappist-1 b may host an atmosphere after all

Publication Date: New Delhi Source: Science News

The Trappist-1 system is one of the most promising for hosting extraterrestrial life. Recent observations previously indicated that Trappist-1 b lacks an atmosphere, but new interpretations suggest otherwise, highlighting the complexities of studying distant exoplanets.

  • The team suggests Trappist-1 b may have a dynamic crust influenced by tectonics and volcanism.
  • Contrary to past studies, the planet could have a thick carbon dioxide-rich atmosphere.
  • The James Webb Space Telescope is crucial in exoplanet studies but requires longer observational periods for conclusive data.
“Contrary to previous ideas, there are conditions under which the planet could have a thick atmosphere rich in carbon dioxide.” - Thomas Henning

This revelation underscores the ongoing challenges in exoplanetary science and the evolving understanding of planet atmospheres.
newTitle: Trappist-1 b may host an atmosphere after all
